revision.text:
{|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin |name=Baby |image=Sopwith Baby WW1 aircraft.jpg |caption=Sopwith Baby in use with the [[Royal Norwegian Navy Air Service]] }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type |type=Single-seat [[Scout (aircraft)|scout]] and bomber biplane seaplane |manufacturer=[[Sopwith Aviation Company]] |designer= |first flight=September {{avyear|1915}}<ref name="Holmes">Holmes, 2005. p 44.</ref> |introduced=1915 |retired= |status=retired |primary user=[[Royal Naval Air Service]] |more users=[[Regia Marina|Aviazione della Regia Marina]] |produced= |developed from=[[Sopwith Schneider]] |number built=386<ref group=note>100 by Sopwith, 186 by Blackburn and 100 by Ansaldo</ref> |variants with their own articles=[[Fairey Hamble Baby]] }} |}
The '''Sopwith Baby''' was a [[United Kingdom|British]] single-seat tractor [[seaplane]] used by the [[Royal Naval Air Service]] (RNAS) from 1915.
==Development and design== The Baby (also known as the Admiralty 8200 Type) was a development of the two-seat [[Sopwith Tabloid|Sopwith Schneider]]. Although the Schneider had won the [[Schneider trophy]] in 1914, the RNAS did not place a formal order until January 1915. Sopwith's initial production version of the Baby differed little from the Schneider Trophy winner.<ref>Lamberton, 1960. p 58.</ref>
The Baby utilized a wooden structure with fabric covering. A [[Lewis Gun]] was fitted, either above the fuselage [[Synchronization gear#Unsynchronized guns and the "deflector wedge" concept|firing through the propeller arc without the benefit of synchronization]], or over the top wing, firing above it.<ref>Woodman 1989, p. 173</ref> To meet the more demanding conditions of 1916–18, Further modifications were made on aircraft built by [[Blackburn Aircraft]] at Leeds, [[United Kingdom]]. A modified variant of the Baby, the [[Fairey Hamble Baby]] was built by [[Fairey Aviation Company|Fairey]] and [[Parnall]].
The Royal Naval Air Service ordered 286 Sopwith Babies of which 100 were built by Sopwith at Kingston and 186 by [[Blackburn Aircraft]] at Leeds with others for export. License manufacture was also undertaken in [[Italy]] by [[Gio. Ansaldo & C.|SA Aeronautica Gio Ansaldo]] of [[Turin]], who built 100 examples for the Italian [[Regia Marina|Aviazione della Regia Marina]].<ref>Alegi, 2001, pp.3-4</ref>
==Operational history== The Baby was used as a shipborne [[Scout (aircraft)|reconnaissance]] and [[bomber aircraft]] operating from [[seaplane carrier]]s and [[cruisers]], as well as [[naval trawler]]s and [[minelayers]]. <!--sub trials were with Schneider, not Baby--> Many Babies were attached to RNAS coastal air stations located in England and Scotland and RNAS stations in Egypt, Greece and Italy.<ref>Thetford, 1878, p. 291</ref>
A major role of the Baby was to intercept [[Germany|German]] [[Zeppelin]] raids as far from [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|Britain]] as possible, along with tracking German naval movements.
Babies saw service with the [[United States]], [[France]], [[Chile]], [[Greece]] and [[Norway]]. In Norway additional Babies were built as replacements, with some seeing service until 1930. Two of the 10 Sopwith Baby floatplanes that were acquired by the [[Royal Norwegian Navy Air Service]] were brought to Svalbard in the summer of 1928 to participate in the search for the lost Norwegian polar explorer [[Roald Amundsen]], but were not used for the search.
==Surviving aircraft== [[File:Sopwith Baby N2078 1 YVTN 17.07.71.jpg|thumb|right|Composite Baby with original parts displayed at the [[Fleet Air Arm Museum]]]] The original components of two Babies built by Sopwith, Nos. 8214 and 8215, have been utilized to complete a composite aircraft for display at the [[Fleet Air Arm Museum]] at [[RNAS Yeovilton (HMS Heron)|RNAS Yeovilton]], Somerset. The exhibit has been marked with the serial ''N-2078'', which was a Blackburn-built aircraft, and has been named ''Jabberwock''.<ref>Ellis, 1977, p. 48</ref>
==Operators== ;{{AUS}} *[[Royal Australian Navy]] operated 1 example in 1917 from cruiser [[HMAS Brisbane (1915)|HMAS Brisbane]].<ref>[http://www.worldairforces.com/Countries/australia/aus.html World Air Forces - Australia] accessdate: March 2014</ref> <!--so called Canadian examples were operated by the RNAS and RAF--> ;{{CHI}} *[[Chilean Navy]] operated 3 examples from 1919-1923<ref name="aifeb84 p73–4">Huertas ''Air International'' February 1984, pp. 73–74.</ref>
;{{FRA}} *[[French Navy]] operated 33 examples from 1916-1919<ref>[http://www.worldairforces.com/Countries/france/fra.html World Air Forces - France] accessdate: March 2014</ref>
;{{flag|Greece|old}} *[[Hellenic Navy]] operated 19 from 1918-1919<ref>[http://www.worldairforces.com/Countries/greece/gre.html World Air Forces - Greece] accessdate: March 2014</ref>
;{{flag|Kingdom of Italy}} :[[Regia Marina|Aviazione della Regia Marina]] 102 examples from 1917-1923 (including 2 trials aircraft from the UK)<ref>Alegi, 2001, pp.2-4 & 8</ref>
;{{JPN}} :[[Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service]] operated 1 example from 1916<ref>[http://www.worldairforces.com/Countries/japan/jpn.html World Air Forces - Japan] accessdate: March 2014</ref>
;{{NLD}} *[[Dutch Naval Aviation Service]] 1 example from 1916-1919<ref>[http://www.worldairforces.com/Countries/netherlands/net.html World Air Forces - Netherlands] accessdate: March 2014</ref> An RNAS aircraft force landed forty miles off the Dutch coast and was towed in and interned.
;{{NOR}} *[[Royal Norwegian Navy Air Service]] operated 10 examples from 1917-1931<ref>[http://www.worldairforces.com/Countries/norway/nor.html World Air Forces - Norway] accessdate: March 2014</ref> ;{{UK}} *[[Royal Naval Air Service]] ** *[[Royal Air Force]] **[[No. 219 Squadron RAF]] **[[No. 229 Squadron RAF]] **[[No. 246 Squadron RAF]] **[[No. 248 Squadron RAF]] **[[No. 249 Squadron RAF]] **[[No. 263 Squadron RAF]] **[[No. 269 Squadron RAF]] **[[No. 270 Squadron RAF]] ;{{USA}} *[[United States Navy]]
==Specifications== [[File:Sopwith Baby dwg.jpg|thumb|Sopwith Baby drawing (shown on beaching gear)]] {{aircraft specifications |plane or copter?=<!-- options: plane/copter --> plane |jet or prop?=<!-- options: jet/prop/both/neither --> prop |ref=Holmes, 2005. p 44. |crew= one |capacity= |length main= 23 ft 0 in |length alt= 7.01 m |span main= 25 ft 8 in |span alt= 7.82 m |height main= 10 ft 0 in |height alt= 3.05 m |area main= 240 ft² |area alt= 22.30 m² |airfoil= |empty weight main= 1,226 lb |empty weight alt= 557 kg |loaded weight main= 1,715 lb |loaded weight alt= 779 kg |useful load main= <!--lb--> |useful load alt= <!--kg--> |max takeoff weight main= <!--lb--> |max takeoff weight alt= <!--kg--> |more general= |engine (prop)=[[Clerget]] |type of prop=[[rotary engine]], driving a two blade wooden propeller |number of props=1 |power main= 110 hp |power alt= 82 kW |power original=
|max speed main= 87 knots |max speed alt= 100 mph, 162 km/h |max speed more= at sea level |cruise speed main= <!--knots--> |cruise speed alt= <!--mph,km/h--> |never exceed speed main= <!--knots--> |never exceed speed alt= <!--mph,km/h--> |stall speed main= <!--knots--> |stall speed alt= <!--mph,km/h--> |range main= <!--nm--> |range alt= <!--mi,km--> |ceiling main= 10,000 ft |ceiling alt= 3,050 m |climb rate main= 285 ft/min |climb rate alt= 1.45 m/s |loading main= <!--lb/ft²--> |loading alt= <!--kg/m²--> |thrust/weight= <!--a unitless ratio--> |power/mass main= <!--hp/lb--> |power/mass alt= <!--W/kg--> |more performance= * '''Endurance:''' 2.25 hrs |armament= * 1 × [[Lewis gun]] * 2 × 65 lb (28 kg) bombs |avionics= }}
